reviews.review_text: DON'T BUY THIS IF YOUR AN AUSTRALIAN USER. 2K doesn't care. No Australian servers or support. You have been warned  EDIT: Battleborn is also a ghost town -which could be another factor why we can barely get any active players in servers- due to it being overwhelmed by games like Overwatch. I've heard that there were Australian servers but when there are no active ones (with players in them) it routes you to servers in other regions, providing a bad internet connection. Australian servers were provided but its possible these were shut down due to the cost of running them (Thank you A Flying Lemur). Apart from this massive problem -which is why i'm not recommending it- Battleborn is a pretty damn good game.

Battleborn started as a fairly decent game that went downhill in it's months, with actual reasons behind it. I first played the open beta because it seemed cool, it was made by the same people who made Borderlands, so that got me hooked onto it. A lot of it's humor seems to be coming from Borderlands 2 other than the slightly worse Pre-Sequel, and much of the gameplay style seems fun and original, co-op slightly resembling Borderlands however, but all of Borderlands mechanics seemed to have been adapted and changed into Competitive Play.  Then Battleborn got ultimately thrashed by Overwatch, people made unecassary comparisons due to it's art style and class based mechanics. From playing both, they're both entirely different games, however, quality-wise, Overwatch seems to be a more well-developed 2016 game than Battleborn.  Competitive Play is a nightmare, with queues that take up half an hour, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ match-ups (Teamed with people who just started playing against people who know the game like theb ack of their hand), and the most common complaint, the player base that stooped beneath 1k, which i'll talk about later. There seems to be balance issues between characters as well.  Co-Op seems, sadly, the highlight of this game. Co-Op actually manages to be fun, but with a few game-breaking bugs in the way, more infamously, players and enemies getting stuck outside the map, and on another note, there are only a few co-op maps.  In it's recent months however, Gearbox seems to be doing such a ♥♥♥♥ job at promoting it and upkeeping it, the game fell apart. Gearbox is desperately trying to keep this game alive, despite it already being practically dead at below 1k people. A surprising two million people played the open beta, then bugs, microtransactions, and it's competitor, Overwatch killed it.   The game's dead and mangled guys, don't put $60 into this, or summer sale wise, $30.

Being that Battleborn has been created by the team behind Borderlands and has similar stylised visuals, the two were always going to be compared to each other. And right from the outset, it is plain to see that there is a heavy Borderlands influence in much of Battleborn. But they are indeed separate entities, with Battleborn taking a MOBA style approach with the multiplayer element of the game, and featuring new characters and a different setting. The premise behind Battleborn is that five races are vying to control the last star, but decide to put their disagreements aside to battle the evil Varelsi, who want nothing more than to destroy the star and plunge the galaxy into darkness.  The initial cutscene does a great job giving us this brief backstory. It also emphasises the fast paced nature of the game with some up-tempo tunes. Indeed, I played one early mission as the sniper character known as Marquis and took my time thoroughly scouring the locales for all the bonuses and credit shards. Apparently, there’s a time limit, and I used up the allotted time. OK, so I did spend a couple of minutes making myself a cup of coffee…but a time limit for the single player portion of the game? Really?  I didn't make that mistake again. Besides that gripe, the private singleplayer (with AI) or public co-op missions (with online compatriots) are rather enjoyable. The co-op allows five friends (or indeed strangers) to team up to play one of the eight story chapters that follow on from the tutorial style introduction. Although there are only eight chapters and there really isn’t that much of a story - apart from the battle for the last remaining star - the levels are well designed and journeying through them with a couple of mates is a heap of fun.  Apart from the playing co-op, there are currently three multiplayer modes, each with 3 maps. Capture mode is basically a Capture-the-Flag derivative where teams must capture and protect various points within the map. The other two modes are somewhat more original. The Meltdown mode has teams guiding groups of minions towards a minion grinder at the centre of the map, somewhat like a bunch of lemmings falling off a cliff to their deaths. The goal of your team is to get as many minions as possible to their destination whilst preventing the opponents from doing so. The Incursion mode has teams attempting to find and destroy two Sentry Bots, with the first team to destroy both declared the winners. All modes feel extremely well balanced, giving teams a chance to catch up if they fall behind at the start.   The variation comes in the form of the character roster, or as they are known, the Battleborn. With 26 characters to choose from, you would think that some of them would be largely familiar. But this isn’t the case. Although the characters would fit into stereotypical classes, their special abilities give them an individuality that sets them apart from another character of a similar class. As you would expect though, not all characters are available from the get-go and need to be unlocked by completing missions or accomplishing specific goals.  Combat feels somewhat more basic than in other shooters, primarily because most characters are limited to one weapon (with increasing capabilities) and their two (or three) special abilities. Unlike Borderlands, where new guns were as rare as grains of sand on a beach, in Battleborn, gamers are pretty much stuck with the same preset weapon throughout the entire mission. But they also have the use of the character's special abilities. These abilities have increased effectiveness as the missions progress through leveling up. And leveling up happens quite quickly throughout the course of a mission, and at each upgrade point, players get to select one of two upgrades to their abilities through the Helix system.   These special abilities can take a little bit to get used to and a strategy is often required for when best to use these powerful attacks. Boss Battles (which are presented in much the same way they are in Borderlands) are particularly important for ability use. These battles can often be drawn out and do provide a challenge in both single player and co-op. Along the way, players will be able to collect bonuses that give short term gains, such as increased speed or shorter cool-downs for abilities. Credit shards can also be collected. These shards are used as the in-game currency and allow gamers to purchase turrets, traps or drones that aid in destroying the enemy.  Like Borderlands, Battleborn is full of colour, and the stylish visuals are painted with the same brush. The cartoon style visuals, combined with the often humorous quips, add to the comic nature of the game, giving the impression that it doesn’t take itself all too seriously. It all feels like a classic Saturday morning cartoon. Indeed, the opening cinematic had me reminiscing about He-Man and Astro Boy. Despite many things happening on screen, the interface is simple and easy to decipher. Shield levels and health are clear, enabling gamers to take added cover if their shields are low. Voice acting too, is clear and understandable, with each of the characters being discernible from others.  Battleborn has clearly been influenced by Borderlands in a host of ways. The visuals, the humour and even many of the gameplay aspects such as the loot crates and shield regeneration, seem to come right from the Borderlands school of gaming design. If I was to sum up Battleborn, it would be Borderlands with new characters and a new setting and an added MOBA style multiplayer component. Of course, as a gamer who played countless hours roaming over Pandora and Elpis, there isn’t too much wrong with that, as all the Borderlands games have been enjoyable. Battleborn, despite the simplistic nature of the combat and time limit issues, is still a fun jaunt, and one that has a ton of replayability due to the characters alone.

EDIT: With the extremely low player base, the fact that updates are really only coming once a month on a game that still needs so much work, as well as the ludicrous new in game currency for a $60 dollar title... I can't really recommend it. I wish I could, I really do, but GBX/2K or whoever is to blame shot this game in the face, and it does not seem like they'll fix it ever.   The game REQUIRES about a 10 hour time investment until it 'clicks' and you start to see the bigger picture. It really is an extremely addicting game and a crazy amount of fun, and it's a shame that it is getting overlooked.   Yet, the game is far from perfect. Having some strange/bad design choices (mostly in terms of UI) and is still missing some much needed things (post game lobbies, better character selector menu, abuse reporting, tutorials for game modes/characters) that a MOBA should have. The lack of polish on certain things such as El Dragon's body slam, or the UI make the game look and feel like it is in beta.  The screen clutter problem and balance issues are extremely overstated, visual effects can be a little overwhelming at first but it grows on you. Contrary to what people say, the game has plenty of content, and the character design ranges from good to utterly fantastic.   I never thought the humor in the Borderlands series was very good, and as BB is a Gearbox game the humor ranges from pretty funny to cringe city. I do find the humor to overall be much better than the Borderlands games.  If you liked Monday Night Combat, you'll love it. If you like MOBAS and FPSs, you'll probably like it.   Obligatory Overwatch comparison: They are not really comparable and both are fantastic. But I will mention that Overwatch IS a more polished game in terms of design and shooting mechanics. Battleborn offers a deeper gameplay experience with progression and single player. Battleborns games are much longer and more methodical, everything (including minions) takes much longer to kill. If you like instant gratification shooters with the kill/die/respawn formula, Battleborn is probably not your cup of tea.

Battleborn is a diamond hidden in a forest. With the storm of 'hero shooters' flooding the game market (which this was the first one to be announced, just sayin') Battleborn has gotten the short end of the stick.   Just what is Battleborn though? As mentioned before, Battleborn is of the new genre of games coming out recently, a hero shooter. Battleborn has 25 playable heroes (5 more DLC characters to come post launch, completely free) that you can play in three different competitive multiplayer gamemodes (two maps per mode) or in a full length co-op story campaign (up to 5 players).    Story-  In Battleborn, you're in a war against Rendain with his Jennerit Empire and Varelsi allies to save the last star in the universe: Solus. There are eight story missions that can be played on Normal or Advanced difficulty with the added option of enabling hardcode mode (only one life per player). Each mission will take you about 30-60 minutes to complete depending on what difficulty you are on and how many people are playing. Additional lore about the game can be unlocked by completing character lore challenges- specific tasks you have to perform with various different characters.   Multiplayer-  If the story mode doesn't tickle your fancy, there's also the competitive multiplayer. In Incursion, the mode that makes everyone think Battleborn is a MOBA (it's not), you are fighting to destroy the two enemy spider sentry bots. You'll have to escort your own minions to their sentry to disable the shields- but that's far easier said than done. Or you could play in Meltdown, where you need to feed your own minions into a robotic grinder that thinks it commands the universe. Lastly, if you just want to get some quick action you can play in Capture, which is pretty much just domination from COD.   Progression-  Don't think that's all, though. In each multiplayer match and story mission, you will level up your character and select different augments that power up your abilities. By playing matches you will also level up your   character rank   which will unlock skins and more augments for your character. In addition by simply playing the game you will level up your   command rank   which unlocks loot packs, loadouts, gear, and more.   Gear- What's that? Gear? There's still more?! That's right- you can also take gear into battle that powers up your character. However, your gear will be unactivated at the beginning of each match. To activate it you must collect 'shards', the currency of the universe. But there's a catch-- those shards are also used to build tactical battle structures on the map, so choose what you buy wisely. Gear comes in various rarities and can be gained by buying loot packs (with in-game credits only, no microtransactions), by getting loot drops in the story mode, by completing challenges, or by leveling up any of your various ranks.   Conclusion-  If you couldn't tell already, this game has incredible depth. This is the factor that distinguishes Battleborn from every other game on the block. Battleborn is a COMPLETE package, worth the $60 in full. Battleborn has NO microtransactions or DLC that will affect the competitive scene (the only DLC will be story missions and cosmetics). If you wish to see how different the game is gameplay-wise from every other MOBA or hero-shooter out there, you should perhaps look at TotalBiscuit's overview of the game. That's about all for my review though. Battleborn? 10/10.

I got this game a while back in a Humble Bundle, and while it lasted I enjoyed it. Sure, players were scarce, and it usually took around 10 minutes to find a game, but the actual gameplay was fun!  I deleted the game a while back because it was dead. And I mean dead. It became harder to find games, and the only people playing it were level 100s! Every game I eventually got into was unbalanced, generally with an opposing team of all 100s due to the party system.   I guess singleplayer is still playable, though for me singleplayer is kinda repeptitive. All the charm of the Borderlands games is there, though.  If there were still people playing this game, I would happily recommend this. Sadly, it is hard to find a game, and is not worth the price tag.

This game is great. The only thing people really complain about is the low number of people playing it. It is a self-fulfilling prophesy. Buy it, Play it, it is a quality game.  I know there is an obligatory statement that this is not overwatch, which is true. But a better way to put it is, this is not a traditional first person game at all. All of the gameplay tropes of FPS's are thrown to the wind; this is, in my opinion, all for the better. People go into the game with a standard FPS attitude, assuming its all micro personnal skill, and no team-strategy.  Battleborn asks you to make good decisions, and punishes you for making bad ones. This is the true factor that it brings from MOBA's. People complain about balance? I don't want to be that guy that say's 'git gud!' but instead i'll say, don't be bad. Dying matters, and keeping yourself from dying is actually possible. This is not a game where you seige until you die, or defend until the seige gives up. It asks you to be smart.  I've played characters where i just felt like i was horrible at playing it, or maybe even had the though that the character was just bad in general. But then prescious moments happen and i realize how well the game is designed. I will think hard and figure out a strategy for a character, and it clicks. I start wrecking. Another weird piece of satisfaction is where i've given up on a character because i think they are bad... but then i see on the enemy team playing it. I get destroyed. The game keeps you on your toes, You can't just get good with one character, you have to get good VS other characters. How do i beat them? When is a bad time not to go in? When is it a good time to charge into difficult odds?  Just try it, The coop is fun, especially with friends, the PvP is amazing and has a great feel to it. Don't ignore a gem because you're scared of low numbers, because you are just contributing to the problem.

Some might say that Battleborn is a clone of Overwatch but this isn't true. These are 2 complete different games and the way the newest Gearbox masterpiece handles in gameplay and replayability is outstanding! Yes there are still a few bugs but these are surely going to be fixed.   The gamemodes are great. You got your Borderlands-esque story, where you have to save the last star in the known universe from being destroyed, and your PVP modes. The story is both aviable for single and multiplayer(up to 5). In the PvP section there are 3 modes, the traditional Capture and 2 new ones. The first is Incursion. A mixture of tower defense with minions where it's your goal to destroy the two guardians od the enemy team. The last mode is meltdown. This is completely new to me. Here you have to escort your minions to a shredder like machine where they are going to be destroyed and at the half of your aim the position of the machine changes.  Thus there is a huge variety in PvP. Sadly there are only 2 maps per gamemode at the moment but there are going to be more implemented into the game within the next months. For free.   For free, that's a good point, because there are going to be 5 more Battleborn characters going to be released. Each for the price of having the basic game and more maps will be here soon as well.  I've played this game a couple hours already and I'm surprised how much I like it. It's by far one of my favourite games at the moment and I'm sure I'm going to play this till the end of Solus ;)

So, I have pretty much no experience with MOBA's. I've never played LoL, DOTA or SMITE and apart from a basic understanding of 'lanes' my knowledge of the genre is pretty limited. So when I heard that Battleborn, a MOBA/FPS game with some raid/dungeon elements, was open for testing I had to see what it was all about. My usual genres of choice are FPS / MMORPGS and Battleborn seems to take the most fun elements of both and combines them together with the fundamental nature of the MOBA.  And here we are, and what a glorious place we find ourselves in. The artistic direction of this game is brilliantly conceived. It's almost as though an Anime cartoonist and a LSD enthusiast had a brainstorming session resulting in this gloriously fun and vibrant parallel dimension. The environments, characters, planets, gameplay, AI and overall universe Gearbox have created is both genius and painstakingly consistent. The whole game feels like an epic labour of love with absolutely no room for compromise.  The story campaign, which can be played either solo or co-operatively, is most reminiscent of your typical WoW dungeon and - in some scenarios - raid! The encounters take all the best game mechanics of a top notch instanced experience and combine it with some of the most fast, furious and colourful FPS action you've ever experienced. The result is... Magical...  Then we have the true heart of Battleborn, the versus mode, where players have the choice of three different game modes: Incursion (defend base, attack enemy case) Capture (hold objectives) and Meltdown (escort friendly minions to enemy base). Each gametype is offers a different player experience, but the true magic here is in the variety of characters to choose from, and the way in which you develop them as they level up and eventually rank up.  I could go on and on about the rewarding item system, the in-game level up choices, the individuality of each character and how the game constantly screams quality, reminding me of the best aspects of all the games I love... But I won't.  All I will say is this: Don't expect an Overwatch clone - this is completely different and in the best way possible. Don't expect a typical dungeon/raid experience - Battleborn takes the best mechanical aspects of both and runs with them. Don't expect a MOBA replacement - treat this more as a compliment to the MOBA genre. Above all: Expect a beautifully crafted game, with a stunning landscape, solid characters, compelling gameplay, genius AI enounters and some of the best art direction you've ever experienced.

Battleborn is a diamond in the rough, but a bit more diamond than rough, I think. It has a few flaws, like some of the map optimization, and the queues for multiplayer could be better, but I honestly enjoy the hell outta Battleborn. The saturday morning cartoon scifi setting/aesthetic is fun, the maps and art style are great to look at, the humor is top notch Gearbox-style goofiness and black comedy that has me almost constantly giggling, and the characters are excellent.  Seriously, the characters are the best part of the whole game. They're all fun and varied and extremely endearing, in the same way that the casts of the Borderlands games are, and it's taken very little time for me to fall in love with most all of them. The lore unlocks you get and dialogue snippets you hear mid-game re: the cast are all delightful.  I don't think it's fair to compare Battleborn to other games; it's honestly its own thing and it's very much worth playing as such. I've found it pleasantly addictive, and when you get in with the right people both the PvP maps and the story missions are great fun to dig into. And hell, if you can't or don't want to get into multi, there's always singleplayer and bot modes. It could use a little more polish around the edges, but BB is honestly fun and enjoyable and it's well worth getting and playing.

Hi there folks!   Battleborn, Released on may the 2nd. (PC(STEAM)/XBONE/PS4) Created by Gearbox Software, the ones who brought you Half-Life expansions ( e.g. Opposing Force, Blue Shift,... ), Borderlands series and Duke Nukem series.  Battleborn is a game, a mix between 'moba' gameplay and a bit of Borderlands. This game is an exciting FPS, whereas like a moba game, has 25 playable 'heroes' to choose from. Characters ranging from melee to long-range weaponary. (with different skills/traits) Ofcourse most of these 'heroes' are locked and you can unlock them by doing challenges or by rank/level. You can level up your player rank, but also your 'heroes' can be leveled.  My first impressions are that this game is not a MOBA at all. It's just 'based' on. Meaning, if you are not so into moba's (like me), you can still enjoy this game to the fullest. With a humour in style of Borderlands, this game is pretty fun. There are enough characters to explore and after checking them all, i'm sure you'll find the character you want to play with.  This game has a story-mode game. Although in my opinion, the story isn't really interesting. It does give some sort of clue, in what kind of universe you are playing in. The cinematics are a mix of animated american manga/cartoons.  The game has a very fast matchmaking, so if you do not want to play alone, you can easily join up with up to 4 other players. Storymode can be played in co-op with friends or other random players. There are 3 other PVP modes: Meltdown (arena mode), Incursion (destroy enemy base) and Devastion (capture the flag).  Also a part of the game are lootboxes. You can find them after defeating bosses in storymode, leveling up and ofcourse by buying them. These lootboxes includes Items that enrich your character's skills. You can only choose 3 active 'powers' that you can activate while playing. These are not character-bound.  This game offers a decent gameplay, loads to explore and a lot of choice in playable characters. Music & voices are great. Although I missed a good story here, the gameplay is as great as playing Borderlands (loads of shooting). And the good/fast matchmaking is really something.  I give this game a 8/10

Cons on this game: the matchmaking still takes too long and is a bit unbalanced.  But I really love the variety of possible playstyles and the humor, both on PVE and PVP.  Give the game a chance, it is really fun, I promise! And I never let you down!  Best served with friends!

PROS - Beautiful 2D animations - Funny Gearbox style writing - Solid, fluid gameplay - Fun with friends  CONS - Not very fun solo - Short campaign (8 missions / 30 mins each; replayable however for different rankings) - Slightly grindy - People will judge you for playing Overwatch Lite  MENTIONS - You don't start with everything unlocked, this is a dealbreaker for some people for a AAA game, understand that going in. If that doesn't bother you and you like unlocking characters as you go, by all means! - The community is somewhat small so some nights it is hard to find a PvP match. If you are always playing with friends, it completely alleviates this however. - The game is often compared to Overwatch; I believe this is unfair. If you play them both you'll see they are very different games. Gearbox shouldn't have marketed it as an Overwatch competitor imo, but here we stand. I play both and enjoy them for very different reasons. - There is a premium currency store, it is exclusively cosmetics, and they are GORGEOUS. If you are against paid cosmetics, learn about ROI on development time vs art time. Also they are COMPLETELY OPTIONAL.  I love this game, give it a shot if you're on the fence about it.

First, a disclosure: The Overwatch comparisons are pretty stupid. I don't get how a modernized version of TF2 needs to be set on a pedestal looking down on a FPS MOBA. I get they were released within a month but, seriously.  Another disclosure: HUGE Gearbox fanboy. Borderlands is one of my favorite game series of all time, hundreds of hours put in on XBox 360 and on Steam. So naturally I'm excited about Battleborn to start.  I love this game. I put 250+ hours into it for a reason. But it's not for everyone, especially not in the early months of release.  First, positives. This game has 26 available characters as of this writing and is planning on an additional 4 characters up to a total of 30. Pretty damn big for an FPS. In addition these characters are, for the most part, wildly different, with varying degrees of supports and assassins with vastly different personalities. Like, one of my mains is a walking block of ice. How cool is that! All of these characters, like most things in this game (which I'll cover), take time to learn. It's a very deep and enlightening experience learning a character and utilizing the best gear and helix (since you upgrade your abilities in skill trees in-game). In addition, the game offers story mode, which is more than can be said about other MOBAs. Then you have colorful environments, rich humor (although the bleeped-out profanity probably isn't necessary), and engaging and competitive multiplayer. It's everything I wanted and got. Unfortunately, no game is without it's flaws, and as much as I wanna say it's perfect, it's not.  Let's just get one thing out of the way: If you're looking for another game that provides a pure MOBA experience, look somewhere else. The game modes available right now are not really anywhere close to modes offered by League or DOTA. Also, Battleborn games typically play out in ways that traditional MOBA players aren't used to. For example, the concept of needing to kill creeps before they reach the objective is still present, but with multiple fortifications that can be built or destroyed. Many players will need to put at least a few games to fully learn what is involvedin winning games and what can make the difference.  The other thing I want to stress is that Battleborn is constantly being updated and tweaked as it progresses, with some very notable flaws that will hopefully be addressed in further patches. For example, right now the game isn't available on Mac or Linux (I think); players in the far east will have a horrible time trying to find matches unless they change their region settings in Steam to NA or EU; Battleborn suffers from improper balancing in terms of gear and characters from a competitive standpoint (looking at you, Alani); and it's not very well optimized on PC, leading to frequent frame-rate drops without some .ini file tweaking.   Gearbox is looking into ALL of this, though. This is a game they've been working on before Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel came out. It's a pet project and people know it.   Now, this review could change in a few months based on what happens, since it's currently seeing decreasing playerbase, and we don't specifically know what Gearbox is going to do. However, if you're willing to deal with the game's flaws in kind, if you want to play a game that is unlike any you've ever played and will challenge you in almost every category, I strongly recommend giving Battleborn a whirl, at the very least when it goes on sale.

*So Far, Soooooo Good!*  TLDR: Battleborn is a great competitve FPS, full of various flavors of combat, skill building, and strategy. If you like Borderlands, the humor is there, if you enjoy a fast paced kill-fest, this is for you, if you get off on the MOBA equipment meta-game, you might want to stick with LOL, HON, or Smite. Overall, a fantastic effort by Gearbox. 8/10.  I had had my eye on Battleborn for a number of months before the open beta. As a veteran of numerous FPS's and MOBA's, the combination of the two had me salivating to say the least. In all fairness, I pre-ordered before the open beta; what can I say? I like to roll the dice every once in a while. I'm happy to report that they came up 7s this time! While I'm not too terribly big on co-op multiplayer, the missions offer something to play with my friends that are, and further, it entices them to come into the online arena to use the loot the gather in the co-op missions.  The PvP is fast paced and fun. Though there may be some balance issues to be worked out, and perhaps the overall player 'score' should maybe be relabled 'threat' (apparently your score has really no value outside of increasing your spawn time when killed, as read on reddit, not confirmed) overall the matches are frentic with an air of strategery that you scarcely can find in any other modern FPS. Match this with the inherent Gearbox style and you have yourself a winner that is bound to eat up at least a hundred hours of my time. If you're on the fence, jump off. This game will grab you and keep you coming back for more.

Battleborn is just a F2P game with a price tag, that puts more value on quantity than quality. Gearbox themselves stated that it cost more to develop this game than it did for both Borderlands 1 and 2 combined. To me, Battleborn proves that this statement was either a lie, or just evidence on how terrible Gearbox is at developing games, leaving Borderlands 2 as just a fluke.   ---  The grind in the game is terrible. Most of the base characters are fairly easy to get, but the problem comes with the DLC characters. It takes longer to unlock a new Battleborn with credits than it does to grind for a character in League of Legends or Heroes of the Storm, two other MOBA's which are both free to play. If you're going to base your AAA game on other MOBA's, why not be more like Dota2 and at least unlock all the non-DLC characters from the start? Why throw in so many microtransactions into a game that was originally sold for $60-80?   Matchmaking is atrocious, both because there are so few people playing, and because of the asinine way it forms groups. Creating a group of 5 random players and then pitting them against another group of 5 often leads to imbalanced teams and makes it a nightmare if someone happens to leave queue in the middle of it. It'd be much wiser for the game to instead look for 10 people and then just split them evenly between teams.  I hate the lack of vision and visual cues in the game. The FoV and the game being in first person works against it being a MOBA. SMITE does being a shooter-MOBA better largely because it is third person. You can see more of what is going on in SMITE.  The sound design is abysmal, many sound effects either being too quiet, unfitting, or nonexistant. The fact that a character like Montana can stomp on the ground so hard that nearby enemies are launched into the air, yet not make a sound is truly bizarre to me. Then you have instances like the spider-like sentry bots whose machine guns sound more like airsoft rifles. Of all the problems I've listed, this has oddly been the one that bothers me the most.  There are more modes than many other games in the same genre, even a single player campaign. But they all feel lackluster and unpolished, showing that neither multiplayer nor singleplayer got enough attention. Gearbox was more focused on including so many things, yet not making them all that great to begin with.   But the biggest problem I had, which is very serious.  This game has actually damaged the graphics card on my computer, and now I am going to have to get a new one.  This card has lasted me through hundreds of games, many of them being much much more graphically intensive than this. But this game has done it in. Even if you disagree with my opinions, you should still be mindful the damage this has done to my computer, and to those of others who have had similar problems.  ------  Battleborn could've been a good game, I was even hyped for it when it was first announced however long ago. But the poor decisions of the developers, and the execution of many of its elements just make it unappealing and bland. There's a reason why the game has a huge problem with player retention, and it's not just because of games like Overwatch or Paladins. Gearbox and 2k are both just as much to blame, if not more since it is their creation, especially when it came to marketing.  After they fulfill their legal obligation with the season pass, I believe they are going to cut support for this game entirely. The game will just continue to die while Randy Pitchford sits in his office singing more about nasty tweets he got on Twitter.  If you must get this game, get it on XBox. That platform at least seems to have a decent sized fanbase still, from what I understand, while PC is like someone who has been stabbed and left lying in the middle of some alleyway somewhere.

I can count the really close games I had with one, perhaps two fingers (admittedly, I only played around 10-15 matches or so) - Ridiculous lack of content: 2 (two) meltdown maps. This must be a joke. Conclusion: This game could have been a real hit, but I fear Gearbox just wanted to cram too much into one game and they ended up with a game that's only average at best. The story mode is mediocre. The recent addition of Advanced matchmaking has been a godsend and I've been lucky with the PUGS I've played with. Except on The Saboteur. That mission is cancer. I've found myself doing the Lore challenges not just for the hero specific legendary gear attached but... gasp... the lore. Oscar Mike being a personal favourite. Performance wise I've had some hiccups on certain missions and maps. I am however playing on a low to mid range rig and with most settings at medium and AA and Physx off I've had a steady experience with fps and no other performance issues preventing me from playing and enjoying the game.  I do hope the game offers a demo or free weekend at some point as there are (and rightfully so) a lot of mixed views on this game the best way to decide if it is for you is to test the waters for yourself.  Personally, I'm having fun and while I can see why some aren't I'm deciding to keep the faith in GBX. At least for now.

This is a situation where I really wish there was a neutral button. I personally adore the game. I find the characters charming and love working through their lore and running missions and the pvp to try and uncover new bits of dialog and story. They're all so entertaining for me and unique that I've only found roughly a handful I can't get the hang of out of the 25 released.   However the pvp matchmaking is horrendous. I could get a match in at most five minutes the first few days after launch, but now I can sit in a queue for a solid half an hour playing a different game on my second monitor and finally give up. That's terrible for a game just released, with the devs insisting on always on play and the fact that versus bots does not count toward any of the unlocks that are supposed to keep players interested and invested.  The game launched with 25 characters, eight story missions that can be played out of order, but still tell a cohesive narrative, three separate pvp maps and hundreds of lines of dialog and unlockables if you're into the characters. Plus they intend to give away the next five characters and dlc a handful of new misssions, taunts and costume variations.   Despite all that I still don't think it justifies the $60.00 flat base cost. The matchmaking it truly atrocious, the always online is frustrating and causes a ton of lag and I really do feel like the game needs to offer that fine balance between running a story mission and then queuing for a match or two and with the matchmaking situation as it currently stands I find myself getting more frustrated and simply turning off the game.   That's unacceptable in a title that released roughly two weeks ago.  I've definitely gotten my money's worth based solely on playtime, of which I'd say about 100 hours or so were actually playing and 30 hours of waiting in queues. But for me personally those 30 wasted hours have cropped up in the last few days and that's a disturbing trend that needs to be reversed.  Seriously just let the versus bot matches count for lore/challenge unlocks. The vast majority of things gotten are titles, costume color variants and taunts. The only thing that's really 'game changing' would be once you've mastered a character you get a personalized piece of equipment with two generic abilities and one specifically tailored toward that character. Really even getting to unlock the characters via bot matches isn't an advantage or disadvantage. I'm a mediocre pvp'er at best and outside of taking twice as many actual hours versus people with co-ordination and a sense of direction, I unlocked everyone through leveling up my command level.   As of the time of writing this review I've only now finished my first run of all the base game missions. I've still got several characters that need to be unlocked under challenges by actually completing various objectives, even though I've had everyone unlocked for days now purely from simply enjoying the hell out of the game.  Seriously though, they need to fix the matchmaking and/or offer alternatives. The game isn't nearly as much fun when you can't get into the multiplayer maps and you don't want to run one of the very few, fairly challenging on the lowest difficulty (I'm a filthy casual though) that can take between 30 and 90 minutes to complete solo versus a pvp map that has a 30 minute timer.   If they can get some quality of life fixes in then I do recommend the game if you like that Borderlands style humor. The universe they've created is IMHO entertaining, colorful and just a ton of fun and considering how many generic brown shooters have been flooding the market for years, that alone is such a wonderful change. If they can't get those quality of life changes in before the playerbase gives up on them then I'd wait for a giant sale and group buy the game and turn it into a party challenge or something.   Regardless I don't think they offered enough stability and content for a base $60 price tag. With the matchmaking challenges the game feels like it's already showing sagging seams. Everything needs to work for the full smorgasboard effect, if one side is broken, it's hard to stay invested or interested because grinding what you can manage to solo starts to feel like a chore. If they'd priced it at $40.00 and the $20.00 season pass I think that would have been more than passable provided everything was working correctly.  Since there is no middle road I'm giving the game a tentative thumbs up simply because I truly love the universe and characters, but I really hope the devs can pull it together. I'd like to see more content and characters.

So I've played this game for a bit now, apparently 46.9 hours as of writing this, and I can say this game is amazing. There are some issues that the devs are working on, and the devs have stated that they plan to support this game for a long time.  The story is pretty good, but to be honest I really only played the story missions in order to get some of the characters unlocked sooner, and to get some gear initially. I find the PvP to be way better.   Currently they only have 3 modes of PvP, Control, Incursion, Meltdown.    Incursion is by far my favorite mode, it has two 'base' cores to destroy per team for winning, mercenary camps, and tons of team fighting. It is kind of weird how there is really only one lane, but it also keeps the action moving. A Lot of people have been stating that the first team to destroy the first 'base' wins through a snowball effect. I can say that I dont feel this is entirely true. I have had matches where we lost our first base, and then came back and destroyed both of the opposing teams bases. The major complaint has been that the shielding minions that spawn after the first base being destroys give the winning team to much advantage, and they have addressed it in a patch making them spawn less frequently.   Meltdown is a 2 lane mode where both sides try to feed their minions to grinders in the enemy teams territory. This is an interesting take that splits up the team fights to be more spaced out, but there are no mercenary camps. I play meltdown a lot less than incursion, since it requires more team communication due to the 2 lanes, but I still find it enjoyable MOBA fare.  Control is by far my least favorite mode, so much that I have played only one time on it. In this mode there is no minions, no mercenary camps, just 3 points on a map, and two teams fighting to control them. This mode feels nothing like a MOBA to me, and the one time I did play it, my team wouldn't work together and kept splitting up, while the other team just picked everyone off one by one until they had a HUGE level advantage.  I also have played overwatch, and I have to say both games play differently. If you want a MOBA first and shooter second play Battleborn, if you want a shooter with some moba elements tacked on as an afterthought, play Overwatch.

Co-Op Story Mode: 10/10. I find it rather fun and teammates are typically good at helping each other out. DLC with additional characters and missions will help flesh this out in the future.  Versus Mode: 3/10. Sure you got the shooting and thats all fine and dandy. But if there are people in this game level 30+ who claim to have extensive knowledge of MOBA's and not know what the merc camp does, it completely defeats the purpose of the game. I don't care if you're the best damn Oscar Mike. If all you're doing is getting kills and not taking objectives do not play this damn mode.  Overall 6/10. Stay for the Co-Op. Wait for Overwatch if you want good competitive hero based shooting.

Hands down, my favourite new game. Not to be confused with 'Overwatch', my least favourite game this year, Battleborn brings hilarity, diversity and difficulty to the table. OW may have some interesting characters and mechanics, however it makes me recall TF2 just a little too much.  Anyway, most of the game reminds me of Borderlands 2, as if it were written by Tiny Tina herself! Ashly Burch even voices a character in the game (Orendi... lol... she's awesome)!  The humour, the characters, the story and the epic voice lines and interactions with the characters and NPCs just makes me love it more!   To top it off, playing your characters to their maximum ranks gives you many ways to play all of the characters available. You unlock taunts, titles, skins, new augment mutations and even items unique to those characters! Everything you do directly affects who you're controlling. It's fantastic.  The Multiplayer portion of the game requires a little bit of polish, but it's still fun! Of course, it doesn't really stick to the 'Moba' aspect in Multiplayer maps, as heroes randomly leave lanes and steamroll everyone they come across. But whatever, it's more an FPS/FPM (first person melee) than it is a Moba. And it's still quite entertaining.  Now, the thing I find most intriguing is the fact that Gearbox will be releasing 5 NEW HEROES and story missions for the season pass, but they won't be necessary for the game. It's just additional content that you can choose or choose not to purchase. Your call. But the Season Pass sounds very worthwhile and I'm excited to see what the new heroes will be! My friends have two theories that have been discussed a couple of times. Will the new heroes be a 'One per Faction' addition? Or will they be an all-new Faction? I'm anxious to find out!  Anyway, let's go over the pros and cons:  ~PROS~ Tons of replayability. Multiple ways to play every hero. No Pay To Win (AT ALL! It's glorious...) Loadouts allow for diverse utility for multiple characters. Campaign can be played co-op up to 5 total players. Dialogue is friggin hilarious... Taunts are also hilarious... Every character has awesome abilities! Campaign is not easy, and Advanced mode is scary. Means I get to play harder! PVP can be quite entertaining. Graphics are flashy and fantastic. After much anticipation, Blizzard's new first person DOTA has come out: Overwatch. It's pretty good.  There are a little less than two dozen heroes for you to choose from, each having a unique, specific weapon as well as a passive and 2 active abilities. Each also has an ultimate ability with a long cooldown that you unlock and level 5. Yes, that's right, there are levels, and each time you level you can splice your DNA to gain one of two benefits for the rest of the game, and if you play a character enough times, you unlock some third choices on that path as well. For instance, one choice might increase your accuracy and reload, while another would increase your base damage.  Heroes are unlocked through a number of means. The easiest way to unlock most of them is to accomplish specific challenges, like winning 5 games with a hero from 1 faction (like, say, The Horde). If you're not in a rush though, you can also unlock all the heroes by just ranking up enough.  A cool twist on the genre is that you can enter a match with a loadout of three pieces of gear, and you spend points during the match to activate those pieces of gear, so you have to anticipate what you'll need in that match, but you're not bound to buying those things in a specific order. Personally, my favorite loadout is 2 Arcanite Reapers, and a hat made out of 3 hats. Which brings me to another point: there's no crafting, which is cool. Blizzard usually overdoes it on crafting, even in their card games.  Overwatch has both a competitive mode and a co-op mode. The competitive mode is a lot like what you expect, but I'm mostly interested in the co-op. Sometimes you just want to blow things up with some friends, right? In co-op, the game is a lot like what you'd expect from a cooperative FPS, kind of like if Starcraft: Ghost let you play with other people. You go through a level doing TF2-like objectives. Escort the thing, defend the thing, or blow up the things.  The characters are varied, and everyone should be able to find something that suits their style. On the other hand, some characters are better for PvE or PvP, which means the full roster won't see equal play. For instance, the robot sniper, the cowboy, and turret are really good.  People are acting like the game is some new great cultural phenomenon, but it's really not, it's just a pretty good game. I guess if you're the kind of person who puts 2000 hours into the same competitive shooter it might be a godsend, but if you're not that dedicated to single games, but you like FPSes, it's probably worth picking up on sale.

The game is excellent for what it is. A FPS MOBA (with a campaign mode) thrown in for added sugar. I have seen a lot of remarks regarding the 'restriction' of playable characters, loot, and lore when starting the game for the first time.   When you start the game you are given a handful of characters. Play the campaign for a few hours on normal difficulty and you will have atleast half of them unlocked, along with the lore for whichever character/s tickles your fancy the most. That being said, some of the lore quests can be slightly tedious or difficult given their specific tasks.   Loot/loot packs are not all that difficult to obtain either, and while i will agree that it can give people a moderate hand up in pvp. I also do not think it is a hinderance or severe handicap if you dont have 'legendary' gear. Like many other MOBAs all characters have their own strengths, as well as weaknesses to other characters. Right now the only character i feel could be considered OP in comparison to others would be Alani. For someone put in as a 'support' class, her dps can be on par if not higher than quite a few of the assault characters in both PVE and PVP, and given her 'skill trees' you can easily mix and match her for both high dps and moderate healing at the same time.  The biggest and only real 'complaint' i have about the game currently, is the overwhelming lack of other players. When i bought the game at release, it only took 30 secs to 1 min tops to get into a group, for both pvp/pve modes. Now, even at peak hours, i can sometimes wait 20mins before only getting one or two team members for campaign mode, only for them to disconnect halfway through a map because we wiped once and 'theres just no point in pushing forward without a full group.' PVP wait times are ridiculous save for Incursion, but...if higher level players dont feel like 'dealing with nubz' they will happily d/c only to have your wait time start all over again.   In short, the game is good but not great, in most part due to lack of player base. Maybe steam will throw it on their upcoming sale and breath some life back into it.

Yes, it's a Gearbox game. It's going to have silly writing, it's gonna have very a cartoony, sorta cel-shaded art style, and it's gonna be a shooter. The balance, like with all PvP games at release, is not perfect to a T with some big-♥♥♥ cherries on top and rainbow sprinkles. It's clear that they did put a lot of work into this game, and if it did well, they were gonna make sure to support for the next couple years like a proper MOBA (because this is still a business, and they still need to make a buck). But with these Overwatch clone accusations (as someone who has played several dozen hours of both, I can say they are not even close to each other and both great in their own ways) and BS balance complaints running rampant, it makes me feel a bit depressed that this plan might not ever see the light of day. You can call it whatever you want, that's your opinion, but if you accuse it of being something it's not, or if you smack it in the face like you would a 2 month old baby for crying, then you're just wrong.  Rant over. It's a good game and a good new IP, if you like Gearbox, if you like shooters, if you like MOBAs, take a good look at this kickass asskicker of a game.

Battleborn is a good game released at a bad time. It released at a time with a fluid of first person MOBA's came out the biggest Overwatch. Pros: + Fun character designs + Classic Borderlands humor (if you're into that) + Fun art style (if you're into that) + Co-op story missions with matchmaking + Lots of characters to play that each feel pretty unique + Interesting and easy to understand progression system (Helix System) + Semi-interesting loot chase (using game currency, not micro-transactions)  Cons: - Very shallow story mode - The requirements to unlock certain characters goes a little overboard (Ghalt, Deande) - Particle blindness - Confusing leveling system - Unbalanced characters - Annoying teammate collision - Very few game modes - Very few maps - Questionable hit detection - Terrible new player experience - Classic Borderlands humor (if you aren't into that) - Cartoony art style (if you aren't into that) - Low population  I do feel bad the game is getting a bad rap for being very unfairly compared to Overwatch. I also feel disappointed that people disparage it for not being a sequel to Borderlands, which shouldn't be held against it. Above anything else, Battleborn is it's own game. Now, the question is, is that game good? No, no it isn't.  For single player - There are only a handful of missions which become very, very repetitive. Many of the characters will come into your roster without much fanfare with only a couple actually having any tangible import to the story (Boldur and Caldarius are introduced through missions but everyone else is just kind of dropped in). Missions mainly devolve into guarding an objective while wave after wave of enemies is thrown at you which gets quite boring after a time. Also, with the voting system for missions players will often just drop games if the missions they want to play isn't chosen.  For multiplayer - I could go on and on so I'm going to list everything below so to try and stay organized:  1. Movement is a chore - your teammates collide with you which makes for some very tedious and frustrating moments of trying to move but you end up jostling with your teammates rather than go anywhere. Playing the 3 story tall Montana will enrage you to no end as you run in place wondering what the hell is going on only to find one of your tiny teammates is stuck under your feet (and I'm sure they aren't having a great time either).  2. Along the same lines of the collision issues if you're a ranged character you'll be very annoyed that your teammates can block your shots. This becomes infuriating as you shoot at a low health adversary just to have them escape because your teammate absorbed most of the bullets you sent their way.  3. Class imbalance - Certain characters are really too powerful for how easy they are to play. Rath is incredibly frustrating has he has a very powerful melee attack combo that requires him to do nothing but hold down the attack button. The problem with this is that he doesn't need to even aim his attacks, he only needs to be in your general area to do damage. He also moves very quick even while attacking making him incredibly tough to hit. To put the cherry on top of this sad sundae his ultimate attack is disgustingly powerful, allowing him to slough off your health while filling his own at the same time. This is just one character - Galilea is even worse at times with her own 360 degree attack combo, shield block, AoE and health steal. And watch as you get stun locked constantly by Shayne over and over and over.  4. Melee stuns. I hope you like not being able to play your character because between Attikus, and Rath you'll be in the air so much you'll think you had wings (or at least had them so you could fly out of the match and the very game itself). Shayne is also an annoying stun-lock type character that can be very frustrating to play against (although he doesn't knock you up in the air, so there's that).  5. Uneven leveling - I mainly played the capture game type which revolves around capturing and holding territories (the same game type in most FPS games). The more territories you have the more points you get each second. First team to 1,000 points wins. This game type doesn't have near enough things to do for experience and usually ended in a one-sided stomp fest (sometimes in my favor, most of the time against). There are shards and turrets but doing the 'buildables' gives so little experience and aid in the form of damage or health that they were rarely ever worth it. Because of this players receive massive chunks of experience for kills, which leads to early snowballing. With things as they are it's very hostile for new players as they run around struggling to find ways to make their character stronger only to end up getting crushed under the boot of an enemy who was the fortunate recipient of a few early games kills.  6. Terrible new player experience - The game doesn't make much of an effort to help the player understand the game mechanics. If you search online you'll find all kinds of people asking questions regarding how to level, which is a basic mechanic in the game. Unfortunately the most common answer to this question is 'kill minions and build turrets' which is unfortunate as many people will take this advice and still be unable to get any meaningful levels in a match as too much experience is weighted on player kills.  7. Snowballing - Snowball is the term used when a team or character just gets better and better (usually from getting fed easy kills) to the point where it is very difficult (if not impossible) to stop them. Much like a snowball rolling down a hill getting bigger and bigger. Snowballing is a massive problem, probably one of the biggest in this game. Due to the extremely large chunks of experience players get for kills, a few early game kills can send a player or team rolling down the hill extremely quickly. I would say roughly over half of the games I have played were decided in the first 2½ minutes of the game due to how much weight is placed on those early kills. Once these kills are made, and players level up quickly from them, it becomes next to impossible to do anything to stop them and the game quickly becomes a 10 minute snooze-fest as you wait around for it to just end (if you have teammates that refuse to surrender to inevitable loss).  8. Long Wait Times - The game hasn't reached high popularity. Some of that is deserved (as it's not very good), some of it isn't (unfair comparisons to Overwatch isn't doing it any favors). This can lead to long wait times for matches and running into several people over and over again which isn't too big of an issue unless those players are toxic (which happens often enough - this is a MOBA after all).  9. Poor Matchmaking - Do a quick search for 'Battleborn Matchmaking' and you'll find no shortage of people upset over the horrendous matchmaking. Newer people to the game are being matched against far more experienced players. Almost worse is random pick-up groups are being matched against parties of people. This is breaking a basic tenant of matchmaking, which is random solo queue folks should be matched against other solo queue people and players in groups should be playing against other players in groups.This helps to keep everything even so the players who aren't in a practiced group won't get steamrolled by those players who are. Consequently the players in the practiced group will get much more of a challenge by playing other grouped teams.  10. Particle Blindness - The game looks pretty, there's no doubt about that however this comes at a price. They cranked up the particle effects on the game and it can get pretty ridiculous in fights as you lose sight of everyone and everything around you. It's like every fight is the finale at the end of a fireworks show. The crazy effects definitely could have been toned down and the game would have been better off for it.  Overall I was really excited for this game ever since I heard it was in the making and after finally playing it it's been nothing but a disappointment. As of the writing

Oozing with style, Battleborn mixes several well established genres into a moshpit of humor, gunplay, and first-person melee. And, it gets most of it right.  Battleborn is trying to be so many things, it's a wonder that it succeeds at enough to make it hold together. Witty, funny dialogue for a cast of zany and unique characters helps polish the whole deal, but the gameplay is what shines through.   Slicing, dicing, and punching feels as satisfying as the gunplay (something the makers of Borderlands know a bit about), and somehow works in the pvp multiplay, and not just in the co-op campaign.  Colorful, cartoon styled graphics steal the show with bright and vivid scenes that leap out of the screen.  Every fight is littered with witty one-liners and quips from loveable characters.  Now, for all this, the game does suffer from a touch of an identity crisis as it tries to fulfill your every desire.  You get a bit of a story-driven campaign that will leave you wanting more.  You get a few moba-style incursion maps.  You get a touch of capture-the-point  You get some tug-of-war robot battles.  All of these are playable solo (with bots in most cases), or online (though you will need to have an internet connection to run the game).   There is another issue: the online community can be difficult to get involved with in the most popular (I believe) game mode, Incursion. It's easy to get trolled, or get owned.  Finally, Battleborn can be a bit of a performance hog at times.  I fully recommend the purchase with the above in mind. This is a game that happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. It is worthy of adoring fans and worth being laughed at, immersed in, and enjoyed.  While not palatable at 60$ (I took advantage of the humble bundle), it is a good game.

Battleborn is a fast-paced and chaotic team shooter that also uses MOBA elements to create a very fluid and dynamic game. The combat as action-packed and hectic, the characters are all recognizeable and memorable, the constant Borderlands-style humor of the game keeps the game from feeling too serious and competitive. Afterall, it's kind of hard to stay hyper-focused and dead serious when you're playing as a bad-mouthed anrthopomorphic cowboy bird armed with a rocket launcher. The story mode is a nice touch and works to give context to everything going on in the game world as well as give players who aren't really in to PvP something to do. The huge amount of challenges and constant unlockables gives you the sense that you are actually accomplishing something no matter how bad your match is going for you, and also keeps tons of goals for players to work towards, which is something that a lot of games should be doing.   All in all, Battleborn is a wacky, cartoonish team shooter that works off one simple concept: games are supposed to be fun and memorable.  I'd highly recommend it to anybody who enjoys first person shooters, as well as anybody who enjoys MOBAs.

They're FPS shooters with a large variety of selectable characters.  While a questionable PvP experience for those who don't enjoy MOBAs (like myself), the game contains a surprisingly well done 8-chapter campaign, that can be played with up to 4 other people. There's a character for everyone, from big tanks to CoD style run&gunners to melee and stealth characters.  So if you want to try Battleborn, it's playerbase for PvP might be 'dead' (or so I hear), but the co-op campaign makes up for it.  Disclaimer : Don't buy if you hate online only games though, even single player requires a connection. (Maybe I lied about the Overwatch thing being it's biggest flaw, it's definitely the online only thing).

Let me start off by saying I just got this game. I was one who fell head over heels for Overwatch, and like many people looked at this game as an inferior and too similar of game. I kept putting it off, but I finally found it on sale and decided to pick it up and give it a go. Granted, I haven't thrown a lot of hours into it, but I'd have gladly payed more for it for what enjoyment I've already received.   Now, the question a lot of people want to know is....how similar is this to Overwatch? Well, it isn't. The way the characters handle can feel like Overwatch, especially with your abilities but that's where the similarities end. I haven't played PVP so I can't weigh in on that yet, but for the PVE I'd liken it to a cross between Overwatch and Destiny gameplay, with Borderlands style comedy. Granted, it doesn't beat any of those games in a specific category...(Overwatch has better characters with abilities, Destiny had a more open world and better gunplay, Borderlands was funnier)....it's the fact that this game is able to blend those together so well, and it doesn't fail in any category.    All in all, it could use a little polish here and there, but overall this is definitely worth picking up. Especially if you're not paying full price. I'd probably give it a 7/10-7.5/10 on any other website, but on Steam I'll have to settle for a YES I'd recommend this.

As a game, I really enjoyed it. The dialogues are interesting and are unique depending on the charater on the team. There are 25 core heroes plus five more on its way. You have the generic fps heroes like Oscar Mike and Whiskey Foxtrot or dual-blade vampire like Rath. Each have their own personalities. Before you would have to unlock some of the heroes, however after the Winter update, all the core heroes will be unlocked at the start.  The missions feels like running a dungeon in a mmorpg; slay all enemies, protect the npc, random treasures, and boss battles. The core game has one prologue mission and eight main missions with 5 more mission on its way as dlc. The main missions are about 45 minutes each and each dlc mission are promised to be roughly 25 minutes. Completing a mission will reward you with gear and in-game currency which you can buy loot packs. Loot pack contain new gear, taunts and skins for your heroes.   I haven't played much of pvp so... meh.  The problem playing in the steam version that the population is low and matchmaking is region locked so there's never a full team of five. Queue times are long; the game really shines when there's more people on the team.   The ps4 community has more people so I will play playing that version. I picked this up from the humble bundle anyways.
